posts.cooked:
There might be a few posts already regarding this, most notably: Use a backup made in Android to iPhone
so thank you for reading and feel free to merge if it is appropriate.

However, since the feature of transferring iphone to iphone has come up, with responses from Signal about opening up further possibilities: Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 3.9 release - #8 by imperiopolis-signal

I wanted to bring up the use case of switching from Android to iPhone and if, in the last 5 months there is something thatâ€™s possible?
Otherwise this post is simply to engage the community on interest for such a feature.

Thank you for reading

posts.cooked: Currently this is not possible (in either direction). However, I agree that it would be a good feature to have.

posts.name: Linh Nguyen
posts.cooked: Is there a technical reason why this canâ€™t happen? Or is it just mostly resources and priority? As in, thereâ€™s serious security challenges vs just not enough use to prioritize development.

theotherlinh:

Or is it just mostly resources and priority?

Itâ€™s actually like that and also the backup process and recovering seems to be very support intensive. Have a look here:

iOS: Backup / keeping message history when switching phones iOS Feature Requests
It is highly unlikely we will ever build a file based backup system for iOS. In addition to it being an unfamiliar experience for iOS users, part of our decision making to not build such a system for iOS was based on how much of a nightmare supporting such a system has been for the Android team, both technically making sure it continues to work with any backup file from any version as well as via our support channels where userâ€™s just donâ€™t understand at all how it works. The future for moving â€¦

This is a little bothersome because I (and Iâ€™m sure other people can relate) want to possibly change to an Android rather than iPhone, but there is no way to transfer the message history. I think a feature that enables transferring between iPhone and Android should be added, or at least a feature should be added to iPhones to backup data like with the Androids.

signal team needs to be worked upon on this, as iâ€™ll be switching platform in a year iâ€™m already concerned about my chat historyâ€¦
And iâ€™m sure there are many people with a similar case.

I made a feature request here to use desktop to backup and restore. This might make restoring messages easier on any platform be it android, ios, another desktop and even linux phone, kaios when they get support in future.

Restore messages and media from Desktop to iOS or Android Feature Requests
I have had this idea that why not use the desktop client as a backup solution? The desktop client can be linked from both Android and ios, making it easier for even ios users to backup their chats. It may even open doors for cross platform message syncing like from Android to ios and vice versa(not even whatsapp has that). We know that Desktop client doesnâ€™t sync older message to protect privacy. In this case we can have only one client (in case of many clients) as main (alpha) client which wilâ€¦

Engadget

WhatsApp's iOS-to-Android chat history transfer tool rolls out to Samsung...

WhatsApp has started rolling out its long-awaited cross-platform chat history transfer feature.

Even Facebook have barely figured it out:

However, one of the more notable requirements is that youâ€™ll need a Lightning to USB-C cable to connect your two phones together. Whatâ€™s more, both devices must have the same phone number. Oh, and your Samsung phone must be either brand new or recently factory reset. In short, the process isnâ€™t quite as streamlined as we had hoped, but WhatsApp promises itâ€™s secure and reliable.

link_counts.title: WhatsApp's iOS-to-Android chat history transfer tool rolls out to Samsung devices | Engadget

posts.cooked:
I have no experience with iOS or Objective-C or Swift, but asking for somebody who have analyzed the protocol used for migrating history from one iPhone to another: from a theoretical perspective, is it technically possible to implement it in another platform (Android, PC, etc.) that passes as being a second iPhone and so force Signal-iOS to send the data to it?

Idea is that once the user is in possession of their data, it can be converted to an backup file which then can be imported into standard Signal-Android, or just stored for future use.
The issue is that the clients use different designs for the data they store. All 3 of them are different from each other. I donâ€™t know why.

newuser:

All 3 of them are different from each other. I donâ€™t know why.

I would guess that Android would be different from iOS and Desktop at least because those two donâ€™t support SMS, but I donâ€™t know what the actual structural differences are, so not sure beyond that.

Oh, this part really makes sense. But my idea was not go that far with the iOS specific approaches, just look into the possibilities of getting actual files out of the device so they can be converted to something else in a desktop computer or just stored in a way a user can simulate a â€œdevice transfer back to the same deviceâ€ (i.e. restoring a backup).

Of course Iâ€™m just speaking of theoreticals here, I donâ€™t even have an iPhone to develop or test this â€“ luckily with Android my data can be safely backed-up.

There is a high level description of the protocol here: Signal-iOS/DeviceTransferService.swift at 6069741602421744edfb59923d2fb3a66b1b23c1 Â· signalapp/Signal-iOS Â· GitHub

The really complicated part is that the process only starts after the new device is already registered with the server (received the SMS, etc.) and I suppose the server and the currently installed client also validates this status before allowing the old device to send the data â€“ any potential backup tool will need to emulate this to present itself as a transfer target. Signal-iOS also seems to look for a service being published through Bonjour, but I suppose Avahi can fulfill this role with Linux.

Step 6.iii is interesting: what happens if the new device does not send the â€œdoneâ€ message? Is the old device allowed to continue being used, as if the transfer had failed? If true, this makes things very interesting!

Apart from these questions, it may be possible to leverage the device transfer protocol to create a tool to backup data from an unmodified (i.e. uncooperative) version of Signal-iOS running in a non-jailbroken iDevice. I wonder how many people also thought a similar tool and how many of them have the conditions to research into this.

posts.name: TK
posts.cooked:
I wonder whatâ€™s the main obstacle here, sending data between platforms, or parsing / packaging data.

If itâ€™s the former, I think magic-wormhole may help. It is platform-agnostic (in python), and besides the initial connection can do client-to-client transfer.

Although so far thereâ€™s only work done on Android. AFAIK thereâ€™s no iOS sample app yet.
